"It would end subsidies, overt and hidden, that favor status-quo fuels and retard the adoption of replacements."

And let's acknowledge that one of the prime subsidies for oil is our military budget. It's impossible to say what portion of our military spending goes to protect our oil supplies, but here's an interesting exercise using ball-park numbers based on the cost of the Iraq war alone (why else did we invade Iraq?)

Annual cost of the Iraq war: $80 billion
Annual US gasoline consumption: 138 billion gallons

Cost of Iraq war per gallon of gasoline sold: 58 cents
Current federal gasoline tax per gallon: 18.4 cents

On that basis, the price of gasoline is subsidized by about 40 cents per gallon.

The true military subsidy to oil is probably much more, including the cost of protecting shipping lanes and, currently, the comparatively trivial cost of Coast Guard involvement in the gulf of Mexico.

Alternatives to fossil fuels all have problems, mostly of scale; they may become viable but it will take time. Therefore, the overwhelming overwhelming take-home message from the Gulf of Mexico disaster is this: conservation, conservation, conservation - it's more effective than mere efficiency. That's the message the President should send the American people. Deplorable as are this crisis and the failures that led to it, it's an ideal opportunity for the President to do whatever it takes to turn the US into a conserving nation once and for all. If he doesn't seize the moment, we'll just continue business as usual.....until the next time.

The President should keep it simple and to the point. Something like this ---

"I command the leak to stop immediately. I command Americans to pay 10X energy prices now so more is available at lower prices for the Chinese."

Then he should employ his most stern visage, to show he's in charge, and declare that from this day forward no 16-wheeler shall be allowed on the highways unless it is properly outfitted with sails.

I'd propose a simple, straight-forward message.

If we have learned anything from the Gulf Oil Disaster, it is that the days of cheap and easy oil are over. Each additional barrel of oil we produce will come at ever higher costs and higher risks.

We need an alternative.

"President Obama, who visited a solar-cell manufacturer in California today in one of his frequent trips focused on clean energy..."

Construction on solar-cell plant site is in the final stages. Local news reports that construction workers at plant site were told to stay home today by management at the request of the White House advance staff; and that is "without pay". Staff in background on TV are the employees of the manufacturing plant. A rather costly photo op for the furloughed workers.

Absolutely brilliant, sir. Here's what else I would like to hear the President do on Friday. Call for an immediate moratorium on offshore drilling, most importantly, cancel plans to drill in the Arctic. Demand that companies operating existing offshore platforms stop pumping oil until stringent environmental impact studies have been completed, all their safety measures have been thoroughly reviewed and relief wells have been dug for each and every one of them.
Too long

As global American citizens (i.e., just plain folks who've been fortunate enough to've been born or emigrated here and who actually appreciate our entire human species as a global reality) we're expected to excel at the exercise of freedom.

As Eiseley so clearly indicated, conscious human choice is a renewable resource that we've barely begun to tap and as Victor Frankl so humbly articulated, the power to choose is our ultimate human freedom.

We American human life forms who've chosen to abdicate our responsibilities by democratic voting (and then leaving tough decisions in the hands of corruptible politicians) and by capital investing (and then leaving market manipulations in the hands of hedge-fund-derivatives mismanagers) have been failing to exercise our full freedom to choose consciously.

We've been asleep at the wheel and totally need to snap out of our comfy stupor. When injustice became legal and when business-as-usual went out of business, we ran out of excuses for failing to read the road signs. Evolution requires us to pay attention courageously or to put it another way, to exercise our ultimate freedoms with enthusiastic engagement. Since there's no conventional road map worth reading, we may want to consider designing a new one. Let's put our legendary American ingenuity to use.

Actual human progress has quite little to do with the things that money can buy; enabling a child to laugh is an immeasurably valuable experience. Designing gifts for future generations needn't feel different.

If "the ability to do work" still qualifies as a viable definition for "energy" and if there's some truth in Khalil Gibran's notion that "work is love made visible" then perhaps we ought to consider our natural love for freedom as a doubly renewable resource. Since love ain't lazy and since freedom relies on responsibility, let's liberate our natural human resourcefulness and get to work designing evolutionary guidance systems along truly sustainable pathways.

Obama should initiate Gulf of Mexico Energy and Coastal Restoration Project on the lines of Manhattan Project. Only this time it is to harness the energy and ecological resources of Gulf of Mexico.
World War II erupted at a moment when the promise of atomic energy had progressed from being possible to being probable. It was not clear whether this energy could be released explosively however.
Szilard, as always, was both a man of vision and a man of action. Well known among European physicists, Szilard drafted a letter in consultation with Albert Einstein that was addressed from Einstein to President F.D. Roosevelt and which warned hime of the possibility of nuclear weapons (the "Einstein Letter"). This letter was delivered to FDR on October 11, 1939, and ten days later the first meeting of the Advisory Committee on Uranium (the "Briggs Uranium Committee") was held in Washington, DC on Pres. Roosevelt's order.
Despite its official founding in August, the Manhattan Project really began on September 17, 1942 when Col. Leslie Richard Groves was notified at 10:30 a.m. by Gen. Brehon Somervell that his assignment overseas had been cancelled. Groves, an experienced manager who had just overseen the colossal construction of the Pentagon, seized immediate and decisive control. In just two days he resolved issues that had dragged on for months under Compton. On September 18 Groves ordered the purchase of 1250 tons of high quality Belgian Congo uranium ore stored on Staten Island, and the next day purchased 52000 acres of land to be the future site of Oak Ridge. Groves was promoted to Brigadier General on September 23. By September 26 Groves had secured access to the highest emergency procurement priority then in existence.
The era of weak, indecisive leadership was over.
Groves' pushy, even overbearing, demeanor won him few friends among the scientists on the Manhattan Project (in particular a special enmity developed between Groves and Szilard). Many detested him at the time, considering him a boor and a buffoon. It was only after the war that many scientists began to appreciate how crucial his organizational and managerial genius was.
By the start of 1945 the Manhattan Project had 'turned the corner'. The uranium bombs seemed assured of success in a matter of months. The prospects for the plutonium bomb were looking up although meeting an August 1 deadline imposed by Groves was far from certain. However, allied military successes against Germany and Japan made it a horse race to see whether it would matter to the war effort. On July 16, 1945 the first atomic explosion took place in history vaporizing the steel tower.
The Gulf of Mexico Project may yield huge US domestic energy resources and restore the treasures and the beauty of the Gulf of Mexico coastline.
Mo Ahmed

what #9 said - "we'll survive this and go on."

And there it is - the attitude that is killing the planet. If it is really true that we will absorb a catastrophe of this scale, knowing that life will actually not go on as we have known it, that death is already hovering over wide swaths of the Gulf and the marshes and wetlands, with still more to come...

Then I see no hope in this US culture. If this is true, that we will do this, then we are a hopeless people unable to change even in the face of its necessity. Expect more disasters then; expect more and deeper wounds to the planet until we are left in a collapsed society facing the consequences of our actions and inactions, our addictions to unsustainable lifestyles.

No, there is not surviving and going on this time. This time, the cost of integrating this into our psyches and just moving on will be an unbearable cost to the human spirit and the future of our children and their children's children.

# 86 Mark B

Dear Mr. B,

Not since the Comintern tried to explain, to the party faithful, the wisdom of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact of 1939 have I read such a confused and illogical defense of the indefensible as your messages to Mr. Jason in defense of "hide the decline".

Within modern times its clear that sometimes tree ring data correlates with instrumental temperature data, and sometimes it anti-correlates with instrumental temperature data.

In any other field of science, such erratic behavior would never be accepted as true proxy behavior.

Rather, it would be regarded as a refutation of the method itself.

In climate science, however, the preferred correlation period is regarded as "true", the inconvenient anti-correlation period is dismissed as "error", and the whole shebang is extrapolated back 1000 years with elan and panache.

Your point # 4, "There is further indication that anthropogenic factors are the cause of the modern divergence problem" is not actually supported by hard data. Briffa and others ASSUMED, with no proof whatsover, that there was some unexplained anthropogenic factor which accounted for the divergence problem, so they could ignore the inconvenient period where tree ring data anti-correlates with temperature change.

So tree rings are fine in themselves for other things, like an indication of drought, rainfall, fertilization and conditions favorable for the growth of trees. Just not temperature proxies.

With all due respect to you heating oil tank, Mr. Revkin, I believe what we are seeing is that it is already too late for some smooth transition from oil to a post-fossil fueled world - for all the gargantuan challenges you mention: rising global demand, lack of preparedness, technology not even close to being ready to make the transition, along with this one - the commitment to a defense budget that will make all our efficiency efforts a drop of oil in the Gulf of Mexico by comparison.

Our problem remains that we are in denial, we are unable to come to terms with the reality that, by not dealing with peak oil back in the 70s when so many were trying to talk about this, we have ensured that the world will come to post-oil with great disruption, great ecological catastrophe, and by way of collapse, not a gentle transition.

It seems our determination is to make a transition without lowering our expectations about what we want in life - endless travel, multiple homes, exotic foods and other goods from far away places, an enormous defense industry, hi-tech gadgets, and on and on - that is bringing us to a tipping point for which the BP/Transocean/Halliburton disaster is portend.

There is almost nothing in the national discourse that tells me anyone, including Obama, gets the true nature of the crisis to which our oil addiction has brought us.

Here is what I would like to hear Obama say, although some if it he can't do legally, unfortunately:

The way of life of many in the Gulf has been changed by this spill and will not come back during the lifetimes of all but perhaps the youngest of us. There are many parties at fault here including BP and regulators, but the nation is also to blame for its refusal to change its habits with respect to oil use and energy, or to implement measures that would provide us with incentives to change our habits and change the necessity of needing to keep drilling for more and more oil. Other developed countries have managed to do this; so should we be able to do this, but because we have not done this already, we're stuck relying too much on oil for now. Moving away from oil, however, is likely to encounter resistance in the Gulf region as these states are dependent on the oil industry for many well-paying jobs. It is precisely because of this dependence, however, that the oil industry, with the help of regulators who were not doing their jobs, operates with seeming impunity and cavalierly created this mess. The only way to keep this from happening again is for the Gulf states to diversify their industries instead of relying so much on the oil industry; their new industries should be in the green economy - batteries for EVs, solar panels and wind turbines to replace oil in cars, charging station parts, and research to improve and innovate all things to do with energy. This is already happening elsewhere - in CA there are several small EV ventures coming into their own and big players like Nissan have sold out their first wave of pure electric cars before even coming into showrooms this fall, and Toyota just formed a partnership with Tesla, a small but high profile EV player. The same goes for solar panels and wind turbines. The demand is there and the products are slowly coming. But too much is coming from China, and we will be switching our reliance on oil for a reliance on China. If the Gulf states get in early, they can be at the forefront as we change our energy and transportation systems and manufacture our own products without relying on China; if they do not, they will be left behind as the need for oil begins to taper off, becoming the equivalent of the rust-belt of 30 years ago, and we may not have enough capacity elsewhere in the country to keep the nation independent and a leader in these new areas.

The oil companies and other vested interests will fight it with misinformation and threats, but the people need to fight back and dictate to big oil for a change. Don't let big oil continue to dictate to those who they provide jobs to and those who rely on their product - diversifying the gulf economies will dilute industry power and their ability to dictate to the Gulf states and to the United States, and it will help the United States recover and compete better in the world.

As for those who have suffered, the U.S. government will make sure BP and other responsible parties, including regulators, pay for damages even if it means seizing companies and individual assets. Why should a fisherman's life be destroyed when an oil manager or regulator who did not do their job continue to live a comfortable life? In some cases, criminal charges may be filed.

What a joke...if this doesn't put the nail in the coffin of this idiotic popularity contest, I don't know what will. I didn't think it could get any worse with Adam being robbed last year, but it did.
I only wish the very best for Chrystal- she deserved to win. If Idol wants to survive, they have to change the voting system. Two bland white guys with guitars, two years in a row. Puke.

Those who thought Crystal should have won will be posting their regrets.  Those who were for Lee are out celebrating or texting their friends.  I tought Crystal was phenomenal and she will have a great career.  However, her one flaw was that she was too much like Janis Joplin, not a bad thing, but she was never oriiginal.  But Lee had something else:  he is unique and shows the potential to be a star.  In additiion he has genuine purity, shyness, and humility.  His voice is still raw but the sound is good and will get better and better.    The whole idea is supposed to be to take an up and coming person who just needs a break and then allow them to grow into stardom.  Crystal was already at her peak and will go on to wow audiances.   Lee fits the role of the newcomer just got his first big break.  He won't disappoint.

Another season again. #2 will be the actual real life winner. Crystal is obviously better. I am very disappointed the result, but the title doesn't matter. The only matter is who will be successful - definitely Crystal will be. We know you really won, Crystal.. be happy, don't be sad. Sorry Lee! we can't be in your side.
Deciding the result by vote is ridiculous. It should be decided by Judges because they know which contestants are really good and have potential success. They are in this business and know what they are doing. Crazy teenagers don't know about it. They just voted by look...
Not fair!
Crystal won last night. They said it last night -Lee is more commercial.  The show's been vyingfor him for a long time.

Will someone please explain to me why America cares so much about this goofy talent show? I can't get away from it. I totally understand that my coworkers, inlaws, etc., don't want to spend their time griping about oil spills and government shills as much as I do, but seriously...is this as good as it gets? How long must we endure?

Say what you will, but "American Idol" is one of the few arenas in which any semblance of community still exists in this country.  People with hopes and dreams and talent connect with massive numbers of Americans of all ages, political stripes, and economic circumstances. The contestants are passionate about and work at what they do.  Maybe it's not high culture, but it is shared culture and rewards hard work and talent, so we ought to be happy for what it contributes to society.

yet again american put the best singer in second place, last year and this one, the truly best performer, best artist, most interesting singer came in second. I like Lee but he did not sing as number one last night or tonight! Go Crystal - can't wait for your album!!!

YES! Lee was the winner from the start! His voice is rich and his talent is strong. He portrays a genuinely nice guy, which adds to his whole persona. I am looking forward to hearing more from him!

Crystal is also very talented as she looks so natural and effortless when she belts out a song. But, she has attitude AND that makes her somewhat unappealing at times. Plus, she doesn't take criticism very well.
Well, America voted...and we're thrilled LEE is the winner!
